article.head: Nine out of ten people in the world are exposed to levels of air pollutants that exceed what the World Health Organization considers too much
article.source: Data from praesent pharetra neque vitae euismod sagittis

text.p: Every breath you take, you suck in tiny particles that attack your lungs, heart, and brain causing a host of health problems. The most dangerous of these particles, which can be anything from soot to sulfates to lead, are fine particles 2.5 microns or less in diameter —shortened as PM 2.5.
Even though air pollution is a global problem, it disproportionately affects those living in developing economies.

article.head: Residential pollution, mostly from generating electricity and heating for our homes, is the main human-made source of fine particles —although windblown dust is still the major source in Africa and West Asia
article.source: Data from praesent pharetra neque vitae euismod sagittis

text.p: Fine particles come from a wide range of sources, most of them from human activities like the burning of fossil fuels to generate electricity for homes and businesses and power transportation, agriculture —a major source of methane and ammonia, and chemical and mining industries. Non-human sources are anything from volcanic eruptions, dust storms, and other natural processes.
Dirty indoor cooking and heating systems, for example, are a major problem in the developing world.

article.head: Around four million people died in 2017 from exposure to fine particles, with higher death rates in Asia and Eastern Europe
article.source: Data from praesent pharetra neque vitae euismod sagittis

text.p: Exposure to PM2.5 reduced average global life expectancy at birth by approximately one year, in 2016. It is a major global health epidemic, causing one in nine of all deaths.

The three biggest killers linked to air pollution are stroke, heart disease, and lung disease and cancer. And high levels of fine particles also contribute to other illnesses, like diabetes, hinder cognitive development in children, and cause mental health problems.
